She is one of the oldest members of the Aleisa borrowing center and this is her sixth loan. When it’s too hot in the daytime, Telesia will do her elei printing. She sells her plants and flowers from home, and she also delivers her lavalava (a Samoan sarong) to the village shops.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her elei (a traditional Samoan printing material) printing, florist business, and vegetable garden

loans.name: Sanu

texts.en: Mrs. Sanu M., 35 years old,  lives in Tangal, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband, Mr. Ashakaji M., one son and one daughter. Her husband is a driver in a private company. Her son left school and also he has no work. Her daughter is studying in grade 3. Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop 4 years ago to uplift the living standard of her family. Their condition is not good so they can't provide a better education for her daughter because in Nepal the cost of education is very high. To overcome this problem she opened a grocery shop. Due to lack of funds she can’t buy goods for her shop. So she is asking for her first loan to buy goods like rice, dal, noodles, etc. She needs to spend her income to provide better education for her daughter, and she wishes to help her husband to upgrade the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods for her work

loans.name: Kawaala 1C (Ii) Group

texts.en: Racheal is 29 years old. She owns a poultry farm. She is applying for a loan to help expand her business and support her children through their education.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens

loans.name: Suhartini

texts.en: Suhartini is 29, married, and a mother of two children. She goes door-to-door to sell children's clothing on credit, collecting installments weekly. She earns up to $10.00 a week. Her husband has a kiosk at the market where he also sells clothings, earning $20.00 a day. She will use this loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en:
Munavvar is 54 years old and she raises four children alone. Munavvar is a market vendor who sells foodstuffs such as oil, salt, and macaroni products. She trades in four local markets, thus trying to increase her income and make her business more profitable. Munavvar's business has been her main source of income for the last twelve years, allowing her to support her large family alone.

Now Munavvar plans to increase her inventory. For this purpose, she requests a loan of 2,700.00 Somoni (US$800.00) for 9 months. Having received loans from IMON several times, she has proved herself a reliable client. Munavvar promises to manage the current loan with accuracy.

loans.use: To increase inventory for sale.

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en: Chhorn S. is 28 years old and lives in Siem Reap province. She sells souvenirs to tourists by the famous Angkor temples around which her city has grown. She earns US $5 per day through her business. Her husband is a musician who runs a small shop selling traditional Cambodian instruments to tourists. They have two children who are not old enough to be in school. She wants to expand her inventory by ordering more souvenir products to meet the growing customer demand.

loans.use: To buy souvenirs for resale

loans.name: Ildika

texts.en:
Ildika is divorced with two children. She lives in Uzhgorod and sells groceries in the local market. In addition, she also has a vending facility selling knitted wear in the same marketplace. Ildika is Hungarian and speaks the language fluently. This skill helps her get some good deals as she travels across the border into Hungary to re-stock her inventory.

Ildika is very experienced and focused. She has been in this trade for 4 years. Currently, her turnover capital is about $4000. Her monthly net profit is about $1200. Ildika has benefited from loans through Nadiya Ukraine. She has been able to increase her income considerably and even purchase a vehicle that she uses to travel to remote wholesale centers to buy inventory. Ildika has always been very responsible and has submitted all loan payments promptly.

Today she is requesting a loan of 3500 Grivnas ($US750) to purchase additional grocery items for her food kiosk. We are hoping that consistent expansion of Ildika’s business will help her achieve her dream of eventually opening her own small grocery store in the city of Uzhgorod.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise.

loans.name: Agamali

texts.en: Agamali Q. is a 47-year-old trader who sells food, vegetables and fruits in the southern part of Azerbaijan in the Internally Displaced People Settlement of the Bilasuvar region. He has more than 20 years of experience as a trader and is married and has three children. Agamali has rented a garage and most of the time he sells goods on the street. His dream is to build a normal shop and continue his work there rather than on the streets. For this purpose he is applying for $800 US.

loans.use: To improve his workplace

loans.name: Lanuola

texts.en:
Lanuola L., 44, is married with 8 children. She has many years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to friends, relatives, and the local community; also, in harvest season, they supply the public market 3 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Lanuola’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan money will also support her kids at school and her church contribution. Her husband is self-employed and works to maintain the business.

loans.use: Purchase gromozone chemicals, sting chemicals, weedkiller sprayer machine, shovel, bushknife, and wire for fence

loans.name: Aparicia

texts.es:
Aparicia is 49 years old and currently lives in the city of Huancayo with her husband and her two small children. She is originally from Huancavelica and came from a farming family. This is where her dedication to livestock farming stems from. Her work consists of purchasing and reselling the livestock she acquires with her husband and every weekend she moves her working capital. What is usually the most difficult part her work is acquiring cheap animals so that she can obtain a profit and increase her profits. She is asking for this loan to purchase more livestock. Her hope is to have more animals so that she can have greater options in selling them.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

Aparicia tiene 49 años y vive actualmente junto a su esposo y dos menores hijos. Es natural D. Huancavelica y nació en una familia netamente agricultora, D. ahí su dedicación a la ganadería al venir a radicar en la ciudad D. Huancayo, su trabajo consiste en comprar y revender los animales que adquiere junto a su esposo y cada fin D. semana mueve su capital D. trabajo, a veces lo difícil es conseguir animales más baratos para conseguir las ganancias esperadas para así poder mejorar sus ganancias. Solicita este préstamo para la compra D. más ganado, su deseo a futuro es tener más animales para poder tener mayores opciones D. venta.

loans.use: Increase in the quantity of her livestock.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.es:
La señora Dominga, socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen del Pilar”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de Lamas, distrito de Zapatero y caserío de Nuevo Celendin. Se dedica a la venta y cría de pollos y cuyes para luego venderlos a las personas que lo solicitan (en el caso de los cuyes), los pollos los distribuyen en las bodegas y pueblos cercanos. 

Con el préstamo de S/. 800, el cual pagará en 6 meses, invertirá en la compra de alimentos de inicio, engorde, acabado, vacunas y maíz, para alimentar a los pollos para luego sacarlos a vender a sus clientes.

Dominga tiene 58 años, vive con su esposo y su hijo, quien la apoya bastante en este trabajo. Es una mujer optimista y trabajadora. Su meta es crecer en el negocio.
texts.en:
Dominga is a member of the “Virgen del Pilar” comunal bank. She lives in San Martin Region, Lamas Province, Zapatero district, in the small town of Nuevo Celendin. She raises chickens and guinea pigs and then sells them to people who ask for them (in the case of the guinea pigs). She sells the chickens to small grocery stores and in nearby small towns. With the loan of S/. 800.00, which she will repay in 6 months, she will invest in starter feed, fattening feed, finishing feed, vaccines and corn. This will be used to feed the chickens so that she can later sell them to her customers. Doming is 58 years old, lives with her husband and son, who help her a lot with work. She is an optimistic and hard-working woman. Her goal is to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy feed

loans.name: Karomat

texts.en:
Karomat U. has been a MicroInvest client since the beginning of 2008, but she has a good reputation and her colleagues note that it is a pleasure to work with her as she has not had any problems repaying her prior loan. She is engaged in the livestock business whereby she purchases and sells livestock. Moreover, she is married and has 4 children who help her with the livestock business.

At present, Karomat is hoping to build a new cow sheet, so she is seeking a business development loan through KIVA in the amount of 2,600 STJ ($775) over 3 months for that specific purpose.

loans.use: To expand and improve her livestock business by building a new cow sheet

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia H. sells fish in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She works from 9:00am to 4:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $85 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish to sell and increase her sales and profit.

Rukia is 22 years old, married, and has one 2-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Rosa De Saron Group

texts.en: Bidalia is hoping to receive her very first loan from Esperanza International (Kiva's Field Partner). She is the mother of one very young child, and lives with her husband. She and her husband live in a very poor area in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. Each day she and her husband do whatever it takes to survive, but neither has a consistent income to provide for the family. Bidalia decided to do something about that and applied for a loan. She is hoping to start a business selling food, such as rice, beans, and fruit. She hopes that one day she will be able to grow the business and have her very own grocery store. She and her husband are going to run this business together, and they are both hopeful that this is going to change their lives. This is the first step for her and her family, and she is ready to take it!

loans.use: Buying food products
